instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3208: What is 820-3208? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V5_S3RS0: What is PP1V5_S3RS0? PP1V5_S3RS0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
Hi Everyone,

Signed up because I have this 3208-B board I cannot work out...



[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]One-wire circuit operates as expected (green then orange light all good).[/FONT][/COLOR]

[FONT=Verdana, Arial, Tahoma, Calibri, Geneva, sans-serif][COLOR=#333333]Fan spins on high, never chimes or posts and of course, no backlight. IMHO, the CPU gets too hot quite quickly...[/COLOR][/FONT]
[FONT=Verdana, Arial, Tahoma, Calibri, Geneva, sans-serif][COLOR=#333333]C.S. not liquid damaged, but the board was really dirty and needed a really good clean. IMHO it was liquid damage from humidity.[/COLOR][/FONT]


[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]On <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>; Pin 2 == 8.4v and <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> Pin 1 == 340mV. [/FONT][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]The resistance of <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> == 91.3k and should be 90.9k, so it's right which makes me reluctant to replace it...
I changed <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> just to test and get the same measurements.[/FONT][/COLOR]

[FONT=Verdana, Arial, Tahoma, Calibri, Geneva, sans-serif][COLOR=#333333]Another interesting issue is that when I measure[/COLOR][/FONT][COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana] Probe 152, Pin 1 on <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, it causes the fan to slow down to about half speed. Then it builds its way back up again.[/FONT][/COLOR]


Does anyone have any suggestions?

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: Check bios area maybe corrosion maybe missing resistor....

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
Thanks, I will check it closer in the morning.
The board is very very clean though. There was no corrosion evident anywhere.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
Definitely can't see any corrosion or any missing components.

Can someone suggest some measurements to take so I can start tracing it please?


Just to reiterate;
<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> is giving me 340mV on pin1 and 8.4v on pin 2

The fan slows to almost a stop then builds back up again if I measure Probe 152 near <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.

<CAPACITOR>C6994</CAPACITOR> gives 7.2v on pin 1, and 3.4v on pin 2.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
No need to measure anything around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, you have a green light so 3V42 must be ok.
Do you actually have CPU Vcore on L7510? If yes continue with the next: 
I have had a few of these boards with no apparent damage and they usually have PCH problems. Heat up the PCH area and see if it works again after, not reflow just 150C or so.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 5820"]
Do you actually have CPU Vcore on L7510? If yes continue with the next:
[/quote]
I get steady 1.125v

[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 5820"]
I have had a few of these boards with no apparent damage and they usually have PCH problems. Heat up the PCH area and see if it works again after, not reflow just 150C or so.[/QUOTE]

Heating it didn't seem to make any difference.

When I plug in power the fan doesn't do the little start-stop-start-stop sequence the Airs usually do. It just spins for a while, then starts to speed up.

Thanks for your suggestions.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
Just getting back onto this board today;

Does this look right? <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL> 1.v35
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> 1v06
I was expecting 1v5 on each of those lines.

Board was working, we changed the SSD, and bang, no boot.


<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> is giving me 1v5 now, but <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL> is still giving me 1.3

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: Measure voltages on <TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7850</RESISTOR> still ok?

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR>::Pin1 == 1.35v
<TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR>::Pin3 == 5.89v (Dafaq? Meant to be 1.5 right?)

<TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR>::Pin6 == 1.35v

<RESISTOR>R7850</RESISTOR>::Pin1 & 2 == 1.35v

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
I checked a working board and the output is really 1.5V. Gate voltage on <TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR> is 5.4V to turn it on. So you either have a dead <TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR> or a very heavy load on 1.<SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> pulling it down.
Check for low resistance to GND on 1.<SIGNAL>5V_S3RS0</SIGNAL>, if that is ok I suspect a dead <TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
Out of interest, how would I find a heavy load?
(A document or YouTube clip if you know of one would do.)

I need to order a <TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR> so may as well keep learning while I wait for it to arrive.

Thanks.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: You measure resistance to GND on that bus, if it seems very low there is something wrong.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6181"]I checked a working board and the output is really 1.5V. Gate voltage on <TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR> is 5.4V to turn it on. So you either have a dead <TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR> or a very heavy load on 1.<SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> pulling it down.
Check for low resistance to GND on 1.<SIGNAL>5V_S3RS0</SIGNAL>, if that is ok I suspect a dead <TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR>.[/QUOTE]


Resistance to ground from <RESISTOR>R7954</RESISTOR> (<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL>) is 270ohms. Is this right, I am not sure what I should be expecting.
From Probe 587 is 299ohms.
From <RESISTOR>R7850</RESISTOR> is 295ohms.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: That seems fine to me. Don't you have a donor 2936 or 3115 board? <TRANSISTOR>Q7801</TRANSISTOR> is on both of them.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: I have a 3115, but it looks like a different chip. It's a fair bit larger.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: RJK03E0DNS seems like a fitting replacement to me.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7261</TRANSISTOR> on the 3115 is a good 50% larger; I don't think the terminals will reach.

Will try and report back shortly.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not chiming, fan running on high.
threads.message: Hmmm, it must of course be physically the same size. Go over the 3115 board to see if any FETs are the same size, then check if it is an N-channel. It is not a critical part, it acts only as a switch.
